very large entity among this large entity of language you can break it down

when we think about the way that we communicate with each other it's not that we're saying communication is one

to want to avoid when you're explaining technical concepts one it's going to be any assumptions of people's prior
knowledge or skill level because you you never know where they're coming in from that can look like saying things along
the lines of oh as I'm sure you already know I mean I've been on the receiving end of this sitting in a room
where someone opened with Oh as I'm sure you already know XYZ I'm sitting there thinking wait I don't know
Am I am I in the wrong here and that for me mentally when I heard that it made me
kind of shut down and that never went away for the rest of that session because I felt that I was lacking some
kind of foundational knowledge and I was too afraid to ask her help because I thought that I was possibly the only
person in the room who didn't know what was going on you also want to avoid using words like just simply or
obviously when you're explaining processes in particular so if you're walking someone through something please
try to avoid these and in saying things like oh you simply do this or you just
click that because what is simple for one person could very well be the most
difficult thing for someone else and you just never know that so avoiding those things focusing more on the process
without giving it a kind of qualifying word like this as to how easy or difficult you assumed that it might be
for someone else also I recommend avoiding dismissive Corrections which
can usually look like everyone's favorite phrase well actually that is if
anyone's ever been on the receiving end of a well actually it is it's not a good place to be in because what that
indicates is that if someone is making a statement like an end user for example
and then you need to correct them by saying well actually that dismisses what they contributed it to the conversation
and it shuts them down and makes them think oh I was completely wrong so I don't feel like I ever want to say anything else here to give you an
example of how I see this a lot of my work at cloud Baker's we do a lot of G suite migrations so you have companies
who are switching into G suite from another platform say outlook and their
users who start spreading rumors amongst themselves because change can be really hard so it's easy for rumors to start
flaring oftentimes people will say oh I heard that now that our company is getting G suite for work that means
they're going to have access to all of our personal Gmail accounts and they can read all of our emails and and then they're scared so in the middle
of a training session someone will bring that up to me and say yeah Livia I know
that this company is going to have access to my personal emails now so think about that statement that I just
made how do you think that person would take it if I started to say my response was well actually that's not true
that's just shutting them down so the way that I would handle that first I would acknowledge their contribution I
would say something like oh thank you so much for for bringing this up that's a
really good point about data privacy or something like that make it kind of
general and then say to clarify what you brought up G suite is completely separate from personal gmail and then I
would cycle back around to saying thanks again for bringing this up because as a whole you always want to be concerned
about data protection and security something of that nature so do you see the difference between that approach and
the well actually very slight difference but what you want to do when you're explaining these things and also when
you're making Corrections is to do so in a way that in that gives people the right information but also encourages

avoid any kind of unnecessary technical jargon or acronyms this is really comes
into play four times when there are end-users who are completely unfamiliar with the systems that you're using and

demonstrate processes and sequence adverbs are words like first next then
finally especially if you're explaining something that is process-oriented
using these types of words when you're listing out the steps is very helpful because it keeps you on track as the
person who's doing the explaining and it also lets the person on the receiving end know that there that it lets them
know where you are in that process so that they're not getting lost in thinking okay wait where what are we
what are we doing here also use shorter sentences I have a tendency to ramble
sometimes if I get really excited about what I'm talking about and it could be a

technique that came out of my student teaching program prior to teaching in
Chicago for public schools I had never heard of this concept before but it's what consists of asking questions like
does that make sense what can I further clarify for you it is absolutely okay to ask these things and
I really do encourage you to asking these questions does not take away from what you know as the subject matter
expert rather it's your way of periodically checking in with the other person to say all right now I've given
you some information let me know how are you feeling about this does that make sense and asking what can I further
clarify for you that goes a little bit further than a straightforward yes/no because rather than than them saying yes
or no your putting up the door for a bigger answer for them to know that it's okay to ask
about a specific thing so again what can I further clarify for you is going to be a good way to check for that

the value of active listening is being part of a community of learners because
he would say to us if you are not prepared to be able to answer that question of what the person before you

I just told you to do okay what one way is what I hear you saying is so you're

when you have no idea what someone is asking you about there are times I get some really vague questions and I just

conversation with someone you're trying to explain something to them and you need to enter into the clarifying phase
I would recommend only ask about two clarifying questions at a time before
you continue on because if you were to ask about any more than that like if you
ask three four five clarifying questions in a row like you tell me more about
this well what did you do next okay is it like this other thing there you see that as you problem-solving but the
person on the other end can see that as you either stalling for time or also you're asking so many questions because
you you don't know what you're talking about and it's not to say that you don't but the balance there that I recommend
is ask about two clarifying questions and then from the new information that they've given you then give them an
answer back so it's kind of like a give-and-take that you ask some they give you some more information and then

communication style are very open to alternatives and not just open to alternatives but they also are able to

now for the assertive style I think that learning how to respond to this

but you know also show confidence and openness I say this because earlier in

help you in that regard and in terms of really making a connection with people
